verse: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming on the road to Atharim. He fought against Israel and captured some of them.
Israel made this vow to the Lord: “If you will indeed give these people into our hands, then we will totally destroy their cities.”
The Lord listened to Israel’s voice and gave the Canaanites into their hands. The Israelites totally destroyed them and their cities. They named the place Hormah.
They set out from Mount Hor along the road to the Red Sea to go around the land of Edom, but the people became very impatient along the way.

The people spoke against God and against Moses, “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? Look, there is no food! There is no water! And we are disgusted by this worthless food!”
The Lord sent venomous snakes among the people, and the snakes bit the people. As a result many people from Israel died.

The people went to Moses and said, “We have sinned, because we have spoken against the Lord and against you. Pray to the Lord to take the snakes away from us.” So Moses prayed on behalf of the people.
The Lord said to Moses, “Make a venomous snake and put it on a pole. If anyone who is bitten looks at it, he will live.”
Moses made a bronze snake and put it on the pole. If a snake had bitten anyone, if that person looked at the bronze snake, he lived.
The Israelites set out and camped at Oboth.
They set out from Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, in the wilderness that faces Moab, toward the sunrise.
From there they set out and camped at the Zered Canyon.
From there they set out and camped on the other side of the Arnon, in the wilderness that extends from the Amorite border. (The Arnon is the border between Moab and the Amorites.)
For this reason it says in the Book of the Wars of the Lord:
From there they continued to Be’er. That is the well which the Lord spoke about to Moses: “Gather the people together, and I will give them water.”
Then Israel sang this song:
from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
from Bamoth to the valley in the region of Moab by the top of Pisgah that overlooks the wasteland.

header: The Defeat of Sihon and Og

verse: Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites to say,

“Permit us to pass through your land. We will not turn aside into any field or vineyard. We will not drink the water from any well. We will stay on the King’s Highway until we have passed through your territory.”

Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. Instead Sihon gathered all his people together and went out into the wilderness to confront Israel. When he came to Jahaz, he fought against Israel.
Israel struck him with the sword and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, but only as far as the Ammonites, because the Ammonite border was strong.
Israel took all these cities. Israel began living in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon and in all its villages.
Because Heshbon had been the city of Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and taken from him all his land as far as the Arnon,
therefore the poets say,
So Israel lived in the land of the Amorites.
Moses sent spies to Jazer. They took its towns and drove out the Amorites who were there.
They turned and went up on the road to Bashan. Og king of Bashan came out with all his people to confront Israel in battle at Edrei.

The Lord said to Moses, “Do not be afraid of him, for I have delivered him into your hand along with all his people and his land. You will do to him just as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived at Heshbon.”
So they struck him down along with his sons and all his people until there were no survivors. Then they took possession of his land.
